label: [eventhandler] used with a supervisor node
info: ## Event handlers and supervisors Event handlers nodes also support being supervised. It's difficult to kill an event handler process. The module that is represents one handler can be killed but the event handler process (parent process) is not affected. An event handler has a parent process and many child processes, probably one per handler. So when a child process dies, the parent process continues. The event handler node process monitors that parent process so that when it is supervised by a supervisor, it does not go down because the parent process of the actual event handler does not go down. ## Process Tree To make this clear: ```mermaid %% Generated by the Flow2UML Node @ https://flowhub.org/flow2uml %% change direction to LR for Node-RED left-to-right UML flowchart TB 089557e075e89df5@{ shape: "rect", label: "Event Handler Parent Process" } -- "Handler PID" --> 8d8f80fbcdad0734@{ shape: "rect", label: "event handler module" } 089557e075e89df5@{ shape: "rect", label: "Event Handler Parent Process" } -- "Handler PID" --> ab05ac8e6df89e27@{ shape: "rect", label: "event handler module" } 089557e075e89df5@{ shape: "rect", label: "Event Handler Parent Process" } -- "Handler PID" --> 23a078dea3c59e5b@{ shape: "rect", label: "event handler module" } 089557e075e89df5@{ shape: "rect", label: "Event Handler Parent Process" } -- "Handler PID" --> 2cca665c497a8fe9@{ shape: "rect", label: "event handler module" } 65e338689e3ae5c4@{ shape: "rect", label: "Event Handler Node Process" } -- "Monitored PID" --> 089557e075e89df5@{ shape: "rect", label: "Event Handler Parent Process" } 23cc281dc7e42e86@{ shape: "rect", label: "Supervisor" } -- "Supervised PID" --> 65e338689e3ae5c4@{ shape: "rect", label: "Event Handler Node Process" } 01ca56ff734b349d@{ shape: "rect", label: "Supervisor node process" } -- "monitored PID" --> 23cc281dc7e42e86@{ shape: "rect", label: "Supervisor" } subgraph "gen_event" 089557e075e89df5 2cca665c497a8fe9 23a078dea3c59e5b ab05ac8e6df89e27 8d8f80fbcdad0734 end subgraph "ered_node_erleventhandler.erl" 65e338689e3ae5c4 end subgraph "ered_node_erlsupervisor.erl" 23cc281dc7e42e86 01ca56ff734b349d end ``` What this test does is actually kill the "Event Handler Parent Process" using the `_eventh_pid` value set on the Event Handler node definition. This killing is done after the fifth event. What then happens is that the supervisor restarts that event handler node, which restarts the gen_event event handler which then restarts the process for the handler that then kills the gen_event parent process after a further five events. The supervisor node has a limit of three over ten seconds, so that this circus is repeated four times.

code:
-module(kill_event_handler_parent_after_five_events).

-behaviour(gen_event).

-export([
    init/1,
    handle_event/2,
    handle_call/2,
    handle_info/2,
    terminate/2,
    code_change/3
]).

-import(ered_nodes, [
    send_msg_to_connected_nodes/2
]).

init(Args) ->
    {ok, #{count => 1}}.

handle_event({<<"a_single_event">>, Msg, #{ '_eventh_pid' := HndlrParentPid} =EventHandlerNodeDef}, #{ count := Count } = State) when Count > 5 ->
    exit(HndlrParentPid, kill),
    {ok, State#{ count => Count + 1 }};

handle_event({<<"a_single_event">>, Msg, EventHandlerNodeDef}, #{ count := Count } = State) ->
    Msg2 = Msg#{ 
        <<"handled">> => <<"a_single_event">>, 
        <<"count">> => Count,
        <<"handler">> => ?MODULE
    },    
    send_msg_to_connected_nodes(EventHandlerNodeDef, Msg2),
    {ok, State#{ count => Count + 1 }};

handle_event(_Event, State) ->
    {ok, State}.

handle_call(_Request, State) ->
    {ok, ok, State}.

handle_info(_Info, State) ->
    {ok, State}.

terminate(Args, _State) ->
    Args.

code_change(_OldVsn, State, _Extra) ->
    {ok, State}.
